Åšramaá¹‡a An Qing, whose courtesy name was Shi Gao,
was the crown prince of the king of Arsakes.ğŸ”½From a young age, he was pure and filial, respectfully serving his parents with utmost sincerity.
His compassion extended even to the lowest creatures.
His words and actions were as if he were treading on a scale.
Moreover, he was intelligent and diligent in his studies.
There were no foreign classics that he did not master.
The images of the seven luminaries and the five elements,
the divination of wind, angles, clouds, and objects,
he thoroughly understood their changes.
He also had a deep understanding of medical techniques and was skilled in acupuncture and moxibustion.
He could see the illness by observing the complexion, and the medicine would surely cure it.
Even the cries of birds and beasts, hearing their voices, he knew their thoughts.
Once while walking, he saw a flock of swallows.
He suddenly said to his companion,
Yan said there should be someone bringing food.
Soon, there really was someone who brought it.
The assembly all marveled at it.
Thus, his name of outstanding difference was spread throughout the Western Regions.
The neighboring countries far and near all respected and admired him.
Although Gao was living at home, he upheld the precepts with pure loftiness.
He lectured and collected the Dharma offerings, continuing with the times.
Later, when his father, the king, passed away, he was about to succeed to the throne, but deeply contemplated the suffering and emptiness, and was disgusted with fame and status.
After the mourning period was over, he abdicated the throne to his uncle and left home to cultivate the Way.
He extensively studied the Buddhist canon and was especially proficient in the Abhidharma studies.
He recited and upheld the meditation sutras, roughly mastering their subtleties.
Then, he traveled around to spread the teachings, visiting various countries.
In the beginning of Emperor Huan's reign of the Han dynasty, he arrived in the Eastern Xia.
Gao was talented, insightful, and quick-witted, able to understand upon hearing once.
Before long, he mastered the spoken language of the Great Tang.
He lamented that the true Dharma was profound and subtle, and extensively promoted its translation.
Gao exhausted the principles and nature, and himself recognized his past causes and conditions.
There were many miraculous traces, which the world could not measure.
Gao first called himself.
He had already been the prince of Arsakes.
He left home together with the eldest son of the country.
When they were begging for alms, they did not meet the donor's expectations, and they often felt resentful.
Gao repeatedly admonished him, but he still did not reform.
Like this for more than twenty years.
He then took leave of his classmates and said:
I will go to Guangzhou to end the karmic retribution from my past lives.
You are diligent in studying the scriptures and are not inferior to me.
But you are very angry by nature, and after death you will receive an evil form.
If I attain enlightenment, I will definitely save you.
Then he went to Guangzhou, where he encountered a great disturbance by bandits and rebels.
While traveling, he met a young man.
The young man pulled out his sword while sleeping and said:
I have finally found you!
Gao laughed and said:
I owe you from my past life, so I have come from afar to repay you.
Your anger is the same intention as in your past life.
He then extended his neck to receive the sword, his expression showing no fear.
The bandit then killed him.
The onlookers filled the roads, all amazed at its strangeness.
But this spirit-consciousness returned to become the prince of the King of Anxi.
This is now the body of Shi Huigong.
Huigong traveled and spread the teachings in China, and his work of propagating the sutras was completed.
He arrived at the end of Emperor Ling's reign, when Guanzhong and Luoyang were in turmoil.
He then shook his staff and went south of the Yangtze River, saying:
I will pass through Mount Lu to save my former classmates.
He arrived at the temple of the Lake of the Cauldron.
This temple had long been spiritually powerful.
Merchants prayed to it and then divided into two groups, going up and down the wind, each without delay.
Once someone asked for bamboo from the deity.
Without permission, he took it.
The boat immediately capsized and the bamboo returned to its original place.
From then on, boatmen respected and feared it, and no one dared to offend it.
Huigong's group of over thirty boats offered sacrifices and prayed for blessings.
The deity then descended and said:
There is a Å›ramaá¹‡a on the boat. Please call him.
The guests were all shocked and invited Huigong to enter the temple. The deity said to Huigong:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
In the past, in a foreign country, you and I left home together to study the Way and were fond of practicing charity.
But you had a hot temper and are now the god of the Quting Temple.
Within a thousand li around, it is all under my jurisdiction.
Because of your charity, you have abundant treasures and luxuries.
Because of your anger, you have fallen into this divine retribution.
Now seeing my former classmate, I am both sad and happy. What can I say?
My life is coming to an end.
But my ugly form is tall and large. If I abandon my life here, it will defile the rivers and lakes.
I should cross to the west of the mountains and marshes.
After this body perishes, I fear I will fall into hell.
I have a thousand bolts of silk and various treasures.
You can use them to establish a monastery and build a stupa, so that I may be reborn in a good place.
Gao said,
I came here on purpose to save you. Why don't you show your form?
The spirit said, My form is very ugly and strange.
Many people will surely be afraid.
Gao said,
Just show yourself. The crowd will not be surprised.
The spirit stuck its head out from behind the bed. It was a huge python.
I don't know how long its tail was.
It reached Gao's knees.
He chanted several times in the Hu language.
The python wept tears like rain and soon disappeared.
Gao then took the silk and said goodbye.
The boat raised its sails and the python again emerged, climbing a mountain to look.
The people raised their hands and then it disappeared. In the blink of an eye, they reached Yuzhang.
He used the temple offerings to build East Temple.
After Gao left, the deity immediately passed away.
In the evening, a young man appeared.
He knelt before the boat and received the vow. He suddenly disappeared.
Gao said to the boatmen:
The young man just now was the deity of Quting Temple. He has escaped his evil form.
Thus, the temple deity ceased and no longer had any spiritual manifestations.ğŸ”½Later, people saw a dead python, its head and tail several li long,
in the marshes west of the mountain.
This is now She Village in Xunyang County.
Gao later returned to Guangzhou.
The young man from his past life who had harmed him was still there.
Gao Jing went to his house and told him about the karmic retribution from the past, and also recounted the past causes and conditions.
They happily faced each other and said:
I still have remaining karmic retributions. We will now go to Kuaiji to finish the karmic retribution.
The guest from Guangzhou realized that Gao was no ordinary person.
He suddenly understood and regretted his past mistakes.
He generously provided support and followed Gao on his travels, eventually reaching Kuaiji.
When they arrived, they entered the market. It happened that there was chaos in the market.
Someone mistakenly hit Gao on the head while fighting.
He died instantly.
The guest from Guangzhou repeatedly experienced the two karmic retributions.
He diligently practiced Buddhism and fully explained the events.
Those who heard about it from far and near all sighed with pity.
It clearly shows the existence of the three periods of past, present, and future.
